reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Presaged a Sequel
reviews.reviewText: Carpathians" is a remarkably good early novel. The world building is excellent, the characters much more well are eloped than the ordinary sci-fy novel, and the plot is both intricate and multi-facited . it takes us all over the universe from Earth to various corporate-run area of space to a snowball planet to dead moons. The six or so characters get about equal time, as the story line shifts from one to the other, Dixon has a way with dramatic tension and he is not afraid to kill off major characters. The ending of this novel seems a bit rushed, bittersweet, and ambiguous. Will Dr. Nya and Johanna be reunited? Will Lester and Per be reunited? Will the Carpathian get out of hostile space? Will Lester turn to the dark side? What will happen to the artifact? Insuring minds are left up in the air. Expect a sequel.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Thank you, Mr. Dixon
reviews.reviewText: I had only recently been complaining to friends about the dearth of great new science fiction when I found "Carpathians." Such imagination! Deeply developed characters, fascinating science, gorgeous world-building and even a tidbit of romance. But I'll never again be able to look at a centipede without a shiver down the spine. I was disappointed to learn that this is the author's only sci-fi novel. (He has a couple of fantasy books but I'm allergic to that genre.) Give us more, Mr. Dixon.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Could not put this book down!
reviews.reviewText: So interesting a tale and pushing us to grasp all the many facets. From travel beyond Earth to machinery used, to many different people and beliefs, wow! Charming how they chose cold, windy places. Brrr! Not for the average person.I loved the idea of nano weavers. What a lifesaver.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars True speculative fiction
reviews.reviewText: Such satisfying read. Lovers of the classic speculative science fiction of old will enjoy this book. Modern readers will enjoy the technical aspects and the science. I loved the characters and story line, the depiction humanity in a difficult future.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Kept my interest
reviews.reviewText: The beginnings of the book was pretty slow but it was interesting enough to plod on. After a hundred pages or so it improved enough to become quite interesting; to the point of being hard to put down when I needed to get some rest. The characters in the book were pretty interesting as was the storyline. I do wish we had gotten more information about the aliens that built the artifact.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Good Sci fi
reviews.reviewText: Great Sci fi and storytelling. I hope there ‘a a sequel. I want to know about the aliens.Recommend this one.Love the character.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A positive step…sideways.
reviews.reviewText: Three separate “What If” statements woven into a single, well paced story. Paul Dixon writes very well by resisting the temptation to over-explain or include unnecessary detail. When the ending arrives, the What If questions have been fleshed out. It’s my hope that Paul resists the temptation to serialize this great thought exercise.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars First rate sci fi
reviews.reviewText: The plot is great - lots of science but kept within the story line, a good mystery to solve (or not), a great cast of closely interacting characters. a satisfying ending and one that can lead to good sequels. The overall feel, to me, is that it has elements of Hyperion, Blindsight, and Dune - three of my all-time favorites. Hyperion because it throws together a varied group of extraordinary people traveling to solve a mystery of cosmic importance, Blindsight because some of them are truly extraordinary pushing the boundaries of being human, Dune because, well, Dune covered pretty much all cool things so it's hard not to be influenced by it.I don't claim the writing as as good in a literary sense as those three classics - few are. But it is not clunky at all and reads very well. The plot is deep with many facets, but not impossible to follow like some others.An overall excellent space romp.
I normally do not write reviews.This book has a lot going on and the author somehow keeps the plots and protagonists growing in self revelation.Highly recommended read.

This is like a novel from the Golden Age of scifi: spaceships, warp points, dueling corporations, an alien artifact discovered on a far planet, scientists out of their depth, far horizons and adventure. The worlds, science and technology are flawless, detailed and convincing. The characters are well-drawn, vivid, all very different to each other, believable and either likeable or empathetic. The ending took me by surprise, but it fits the logic of this universe.Thoughtful, involving, fantastic, believable, unusual, all the classic virtues of scifi. Give yourself a treat!
